content: The "Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices Act of 1996" aims to address existing problems in Federal election laws in a nonpartisan manner, considering constitutional freedoms of speech and association. It acknowledges the bias favoring incumbent Members of Congress and the historical difficulty in reforming these laws. The "Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices" is established to study and recommend legislation to reform laws related to elections for Federal office. The Commission aims to address existing problems in Federal election laws in a nonpartisan manner. The Commission, composed of 12 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, must consist of individuals not in Congress and with specific qualifications. The President consults various leaders for appointments. The Commission, appointed by the President with Senate approval, consists of 12 members not affiliated with the Republican or Democratic Party. The President designates a Chairman who also cannot be affiliated with either party. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and no more than 4 members can be from the same political party. The President designates a Chairman who also cannot be affiliated with either party. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and no more than 4 members can be from the same political party. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as it considers appropriate. Seven members constitute a quorum, and a majority is required for approving legislation. Any member can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission members, excluding the Chairman, receive pay based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate, while the Chairman receives pay based on level III. They also receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission appoints a staff director independently. The Commission appoints a staff director who is paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Chair can appoint necessary personnel without following certain provisions of title 5, United States Code, but their pay cannot exceed the maximum for grade GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Chair can procure temporary and intermittent services under section 5332 of title 5, United States Code, to the same extent as authorized by section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. REPORT AND RECOMMENDED LEGISLATION. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of selecting the Chair, including recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns. If 7 or more members agree on a recommendation, they must prepare legislation to implement it for expedited Congressional consideration. The Commission's recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns must be implemented through legislation, following the provisions of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990. Special rules apply for the consideration of the legislation by the Committee on House Oversight and the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate. The Committee on Armed Services of the Senate will be referred to as the Committee on Rules and Administration. References to the date of report transmission will be considered the date of recommendation submission. Special rules allow for amendments to legislation by the majority leader of the House or Senate. The special rules allow for amendments in the nature of a substitute to legislation offered by the minority leader of the House of Representatives or the Senate. Separate votes will be taken on each amendment and the original legislation. If multiple versions of the legislation are adopted, the version with the most votes will be deemed passed by that House. The Commission's primary objectives include promoting fair elections, reducing special interest influence, and leveling the playing field for incumbent Members of Congress. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report and is authorized to receive necessary appropriations.
